prompts.prompt: What is a meme, and what's the history behind this word?

outputs:
A meme is an idea, behavior or style that spreads from person to person within a culture. It can be thought of as an analogy for how genes work in biology; just like hereditary traits are passed down through generations, cultural ideas spread similarly, mutating along the way. The term "meme" was coined by Richard Dawkins in his book 'The Selfish Gene' (1976) where he described it as something which replicates itself exactly whilst changing over time at each reproduction resulting into different copies according to their environmental pressures - thus explaining its widespread prevalence today across various forms including visuals such as pictures with text overlayed onto them known popularly as image macros among internet users worldwide.
Memes have been around since ancient times but only gained significant attention during modernity when mass media became more accessible than ever before allowing individuals greater opportunity propagate certain images/ideas globally instantaneously revolutionizing communication networks leading us towards digital age we now live-in today facilitated large scale transmission information sharing much faster pace unimaginable prior human civilization existed..<|endoftext|>

A "meme" is an idea or cultural practice that spreads from person to person within a society. The term was coined by Richard Dawkins in his 1976 book “The Selfish Gene.” According to Dawkins:

“A meme,” he writes, “is something that one mind copies into its own brain, making it more like itself; thus passing on informational genes for survival of the replicator… A good example would be a mating call — which can only spread if there are enough males around who learn to recognize and respond appropriately to the message.” 

Dawkins used the metaphorical concept of "genes for ideas” because at first glance they seem very different – genetic material versus symbols representing abstract concepts – but just as DNA gets copied during cell division so too do these symbolic units called 'ideas' get passed down through culture from one individual to another. This ability has since been found across many species including humans where language allows us to store knowledge about ourselves and others over generations leading ultimately towards progressive developmental stages such as artistic expression amongst other things. In essence then, our brains act both as recipients AND transmitters simultaneously shaping notions regarding how we live with eachother today - hence why social norms change faster than biological ones sometimes!<|endoftext|>

The term "meme" comes from Richard Dawkins' 1976 book "Memes: The New Science." In it he defined the concept as something that can be imitated or replicated by others. A modern-day meme differs in meaning to how Dawkins envisaged, instead often being used interchangeably for viral images with humorous captions; though the original definition still holds true for certain types of cultural ideas like fashion fads[1].
According to Wikipedia, there are various etymological sources claiming an origin different from each other. Two popular possibilities arise from Greek πρῶτος (pros) “first” + μέμα (-ema), literally ‘that which precedes’, thus implying superiority to the one who was previously following such example. Another possibility relies on French méme meaning ‘an image reproduced onto paper through photography etcetera [1].” It appears both these origins were inspired at least partially due to early art forms known today commonly only via analog media precluding digital reproduction methods until later times—hence leading some people consider alternate explanations based more solidly upon those older systems without reliance solely towards electronic/digital age paradigms alone.”<|endoftext|>

A "meme" (rhymes with tree) is an idea or style that spreads from person to person within a culture. It can be visual (like a photograph), auditory (such as a song), gestural (like a dance move), written (as in a catchphrase). Some examples would include viral photos like the Dancing Baby videos of Romeo Beckham circa 2015; words and phrases such as Yanny vs Laurel which went viral for five days until it was discovered to all actually say either “Yanny” or “Laurel”. The term originated in Richard Dawkins’ book *The Selfish Gene*. In one chapter he described how ideas could spread throughout cultures via imitation because they are stored as segments of DNA. As these sections become more successful at replicating themselves over time then eventually replace other lesser-used ones - thus leading individuals towards shared interests/values etcetera
As far back into human societal existence goes meming hasn't really occurred due simply not existing yet… although maybe there were early instances where groups used symbols instead language—some believe so! For example caves paintings may contain stylized animal forms created by Neanderthals thousands upon thousands years ago now believed through interpretation indicate meaning when viewed collectively amongst their kinsmen/villagers. However we don't have definitive records indicating anything similar happened before writing came along around ~3400BC Cuniform Egyptians etched first hieroglyphics onto rock walls using reeds dipped ink made natural plant materials--which later lead ancient scholars deciphering myriad languages spoken across entire continents alike today!<|endoftext|>

A meme is an idea, behavior or style that spreads from person to person within a culture. It was coined by Richard Dawkins in his 1976 book "The Selfish Gene" as an analogy for how genes propagate themselves culturally.
Memes are not necessarily true statements (as they do not need to be) but instead serve more of an explanatory function similar to how science uses models: providing ways of thinking about complex issues through metaphors, stories etcetera so people can understand them better - sort of like explaining difficult things using easier-to-understand concepts borrowed from other fields/domains; these'models' might even start off false if there happens also be truth contained amongst those elements. A famous example would probably involve Albert Einstein's relativity equations which he developed over several years after observing something odd going on when objects approached speeds close enough together while passing each other during train travel — thus resulting both profoundly surprising observations *and* deep insights into some basic laws underlying all our daily experiences such us space/time continuum properties! Another one could refer specifically at biological reproduction process where certain mutations become passed downwards from generation following others creating unique genetic configurations found only inside individual organisms we observe today — hence making evolution happen despite appearances indicating otherwise… In summary though, no two copies should look identical because slight differences lead either toward success/survival advantages or simply new variations helping populations adapt according circumstances arise across different environments encountered along their respective journey(s).
Some common features seen with regard social spread include imitation based reinforcement loops encouraging repetition due rewards gained from being noticed performing acts related given ideas (positive feedback), copying behaviour associated individuals previously observed doing positive thing rather than negative ones since disliking outcomes experienced first time round will usually avoid repeating it again under most situations regardless any consequences received initially...

A meme is an idea, behavior or style that spreads from person to person within a culture. It was coined by Richard Dawkins in his 1976 book "The Selfish Gene" where he wrote:
> A cultural molecule which replicates faithfully even if its genetic message mutates slightly on each occasion it goes around - hence "meme".<|endoftext|>

A "meme" is an idea or cultural item that spreads from person to person within a society. It can be thought of as being analogous to genes in biology: just like how DNA contains genetic information which passes on characteristics from one generation to another through reproduction; similarly ideas are passed down between individuals over time.

The term comes from Richard Dawkins' 1976 book "The Selfish Gene", where he used it describe these self-replicating units (which later became known more broadly). The concept has since been popularized by evolutionary psychologists such as Steve Pinker who use it often when discussing topics related to culture and human behavior/mentality etcetera. In essence any type of shared mental experience could potentially become considered'memetic material', thus making it susceptible for mutation & further adaptation depending upon various environmental pressures acting upon said collective consciousness at large(evolution).

In addition there exists other forms beyond traditional visual arts based representations -such as language structures / religions / ideologies…all share certain key attributes associated with successful transmission i.e.: simplicity, humor appealability..etc...This means even nonverbal expressions might also qualify under its scope if deemed universally understood by significant portion global populations! 

Therefore understanding ‘meme’ entails examining factors influencing how well they propagate throughout population while taking into account not only verbal communication but contextual elements surrounding them too – whether via personal interaction face-to-face conversation media exposure online content consumption …the list goes endless really…just ask someone familiarizing themselves thoroughly about different types classifications categorization criteria utilised around world today 🙂🌎💻📱👀🔍🧠🤔<|endoftext|>

A "meme" is an idea or cultural unit that spreads from person to person within a society. It was coined by Richard Dawkins in his 1976 book *The Selfish Gene*, where he used it as an analogy for how ideas spread through populations like genes do in biology. The term has since been popularized outside of science circles due to its use on social media platforms such as Reddit, which hosts communities dedicated to sharing content known as "memes".

Dawkins originally introduced the concept of memes while discussing altruism among animals; according to him, some behaviors may become more common simply because they help others perform those same acts - similarly, information can be transmitted rapidly throughout a culture when something entertaining/funny catches people’s attention (a type of ‘attention-getting device’). In order words: A “meme” refers not just to images but also textual jokes or other types of cultural symbols passed along between individuals through conversation etcetera.” This definition still holds true today even though technology makes distribution much easier than ever before! 

Overall then—even if we take out Darwinian explanations about genealogical units replicating themselves into future generations–the meaning remains consistent with original conception given nearly forty years ago : Some bits/pieces stick around long enough to shape new trends after being communicated widely across various networks connecting humanity together regardless borders race creed colour language anything else keeping us apart at first glance..<|endoftext|>

A meme (pronounced as "meme") is an idea or behavior that spreads from person to person within a society. The term was coined by Richard Dawkins in his book *The Selfish Gene* published in 1976. It comes from the Greek words μήμα ("mēma"), meaning "something that is imitated," and ἐμβολός ("embolós"), meaning "imitator" or "follower."

Memes are often humorous images with text overlays used on social media platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr etcetera. They can also include viral videos, catchphrases phrases like "Yanny vs Laurel", jokes, songs, artwork etc., which may be passed around through digital communication channels rapidly because they provide entertainment value for their audience while being easy-to understand even if one hasn't seen it before; thus increasing its chances of getting replicated further down along chains formed due people copying other peoples reactions/responses when confronted about certain things online..

There have been many examples throughout time where new ideas spread quickly amongst humans based solely upon novelty & shared amusement provided by something interesting found elsewhere - think how fast information travelled during medieval times via scrolls written across long distances between cities only recently discovered after centuries! These days however we see these phenomena happening more frequently since everyone has internet access globally now making sharing much easier than ever before...<|endoftext|>

A meme (or “meme”) is an idea, behavior or style that spreads from person to person within a culture. It can be visual or verbal in nature but often both. The term was coined by Richard Dawkins in his 1976 book "The Selfish Gene" where he described how cultural information could spread like genes through imitation of others with similar characteristics

The origin of memes comes from two Greek words: mimeme meaning ‘imitate’; and genein which means ‘to come down from above’ – so together they mean something we inherit from other people rather than being genetically determined ourselves.”

Memetics studies how these ideas evolve over time based on factors such as mutation rates among individuals copying them along social networks/groups who share values etc.. In summary - it explores why certain things become popular while other less successful ones fade away into obscurity without passing onto future generations via biological evolution.<|endoftext|>

A "meme" (pronounced /ˈmiːm/) is an idea, behavior or style that spreads from person to person within a culture. The term was coined by Richard Dawkins in his 1976 book *The Selfish Gene*. He used it as shorthand for cultural information which he saw as analogous to genes:
> A gene is something you get from your parents; a meme, on the other hand, is something you catch from your peers."
Dawkins' use of the term caught on quickly among biologists and others interested in evolutionary psychology, but its precise meaning has been debated ever since. Some have argued that there are no such things as true'memes', while others see them as important units of cultural transmission alongside language and religion. In recent years, however, interest in memetics - the scientific study of how ideas spread through populations – has grown rapidly again thanks largely due social media platforms like Facebook where users share content with friends who then pass those same posts onto their own networks creating viral trends over time periods measured in days rather than generations!<|endoftext|>

prompts.prompt: I'm sad. How can I be happy?

outputs:
There are many ways to bring happiness into your life, even if it feels like things are going wrong or you're in a difficult situation right now:
- Connect with others and engage in positive social activities - spending time talking about what is good in the world and connecting through shared interests can help shift focus from problems towards solutions that lead us closer together as humans on this planet. This doesn't have to mean joining some kind of club either; just having conversations over coffee with friends will do wonders for improving mood! 
- Practice gratitude by keeping track each day (or week) at least three times during which something happened thanks only because someone did care enough about themself/you both mentally & physically too. By doing so consistently everyday one could notice gradual improvements after few weeks' time due its impact upon brain chemistry levels positively shifting leading ultimately toward overall better wellbeing state psychologically speaking. 
	It’s important not confuse these feelings with temporary distractions caused by external stimuli such drug abuse, video games addiction etc.. In order truly appreciate real meaning behind momentary pleasures brought forth via experiences gained throughout our lives thus far would require effortful work done purposefully seeking contentment within self regardless circumstances surrounding environment around us. 
	
	
*Please note though everyone's experience differs based upon various factors including genetics upbringing culture background lifestyle choices priorities values expectations goals aspirations personal history traumatic events experienced before present ones occurring currently.*


Let me know how else might assist further today 😊<|endoftext|>

You could try looking on the bright side of things, or doing something that makes you feel good like spending time with friends and family, helping someone out who needs it (volunteering), being creative through arts such as drawing painting writing poetry etc., learning a new skill in an area you are interested to help pass your free time more productively, eating healthy food which gives energy for better physical health, exercising daily which also helps increase happiness levels and many others depending upon what would bring pleasure into life from various sources. 

If these suggestions do not work for you then there might be underlying issues causing depression and other mental health problems where professional medical advice is needed so please take care about yourself and don't hesitate seeking assistance when required!<|endoftext|>

If you're feeling down, it's important to take care of yourself and try to engage in activities that bring you joy or help distract your mind from negative thoughts. Some things that might make you feel better include:
* Reach out to friends and loved ones for support
* Take a walk outside if weather permits (Fresh air/sunlight helps boost endorphins!)
* Do something creative like drawing, writing or playing an instrument - taking time for self-expression often leads to happiness. 
* Engage with positive people on the internet by reading blogs written by those who share similar interests as yours!

Remember always stay patient; life is filled with ups & down but hope exists throughout all challenges so never stop looking forward towards brighter days ahead 🌞🎉.<|endoftext|>

Exercise and eating a balanced diet can make you feel better both mentally and physically by releasing endorphins in your body which are mood enhancers, they also help to boost self esteem as when we look after our bodies then others may notice it resulting with us feeling happier about ourselves thus giving more confidence overall therefore helping on the road to becoming cheerful again plus doing activities like socializing or pursuing hobbies is good for maintaining friendships reducing stress levels improving sleep quality increasing enjoyment of life these aspects lead onto being able to cope well under pressure so if done effectively makes you much less likely to fall victim depression my best advice would probably come from getting professional medical advise because im not qualified nor medically trained but this should at least offer some guidance i hope you find what works for yourself! 
Remember its important taking care takes time sometimes longer than other times but consistency matters ultimately! Its okay that things take their course do try seeking support along the way though ❤️💚🌟🎶 #mentalhealthawarenessmonth #happiness #balance#exerciseanddietiskeyforbothmindbodyandsoul<|endoftext|>

It's great when we get together with our loved ones as this provides a social connection which has been shown to increase levels of dopamine in the brain leading to an overall better mood - however if that isn't possible there are still other ways such as exercising outdoors (if it is safe) for fresh air & Vitamin D exposure; reading a good book or listening music (you may wish to check out "Binaural Beats" audio files available online); writing down what brings pleasure / gratitude into your life right now could also help put things back onto track again by shifting focus towards positivity.

Please remember that everyone reacts differently so don’t give up trying new techniques until something sticks! You're never alone even though sometimes might appear that way from my responses :) Please stay safe whatever measures required locally xo<|endoftext|>

Exercise is known to improve mental health by reducing stress and increasing the production of endorphins, which are hormones that promote feelings of happiness and well-being. Other things you could do include eating a healthy diet rich in whole foods like fruits vegetables nuts legumes fish and olive oil avoiding smoking alcohol and drugs engaging with loved ones or finding supportive relationships taking time for yourself through activities such as meditation yoga or journaling volunteering at your local animal rescue helping others out whenever possible doing something nice for someone else trying new experiences travel etc.

prompts.prompt: Please help me with designing an intuitive navigation system for my new mobile application.

Designing a great user experience starts by understanding your users' needs and how they navigate through different platforms. Here are some tips to consider when creating the perfect navigation:

1. Make it simple - Users should be able to find what they're looking for quickly, so keep menus short and use icons or text that's easy to read on small screens.

2. Use familiar patterns - Stick to common conventions like left/right handed swipes as well as top tabs and bottom bars which will make navigating feel natural even if someone has not used this app before.

3. Keep in mind accessibility issues such as color contrast between foreground elements against backgrounds that could pose difficulties for people who have low vision; also ensure larger font sizes can easily display without straining eyesight 

4.Provide visual cues- Consider adding feedback mechanisms (such as animations) throughout key touchpoints within sections of content (e.g., next/previous buttons); these will provide instant feedback about where they currently reside inside certain pages without having them rely solely upon written labels alone!


5.Categorize items appropriately- Group similar functions together into categories based either semantically related information(i.e grouping restaurants under food category), geographical proximity (cities near you would fall under location section etc.),or alphabetical order for easier discovery  

6.Consider speed & responsiveness– Ensure all features work seamlessly across devices including slow connections due frequent updates requiring fast loading times while avoiding any lag during transitions between screens   
 

By keeping these aspects at heart,you'll end up crafting something wonderful both visually appealing yet functional enough to meet your goals successfully.. Happy Navigation!<|endoftext|>

prompts.prompt: Tell me some tips on how to color grade and edit a moody, horror-themed render made in Unreal Engine 5 using DaVinci Resolve. Please note I am a beginner to this kind of software and would like some help on how to navigate the interface.

outputs:
Sure! Here are some basic steps for editing your moody, horror-themed render in DaVinci Resolve:

1. Import Your Render - Firstly import your rendered image into DaVinci Resolve by clicking on "File" > "Open Project". Locate where you saved your render (usually under Documents/DaVinci Resolve) and double click it to open the project file.
2. Color Grading - Once imported, select the clip that represents your entire render from the timeline located at bottom right corner or press CRTL+A to Select all clips. Then go over to Effects tab>Color Correction
3. Tone Mapping - Next is tone mapping which helps bring out details in dark areas while keeping bright colors intact as well smoothing out skin tones etc., so look up settings such as High Contrast Adaptive Exposure mode & ACEScc profiles 
4.LUT's - Look into adding Lut(Look Up Tables). You can download free ones online or create custom one based off reference images found through google search engine  
5.Saturation Control- Lastly add Saturation control adjustments especially around mood lightings area, shadows & highlights will also play role here. Adjust accordingly till desired effect has been achieved!

Remember there isn't necessarily an exact science when grading; try playing with different values until finding what works best for each shot individually but keep consistent throughout process.. Happy Editing :)<|endoftext|>

Here are some general steps you can follow for editing your scene:

1. Import the rendered image from Unreal Engine into DaVinci Resolve by dragging it onto the timeline or clicking "File > Open" at the top left corner of the screen.
2. Use the tools available under the "Nodes" tab (located near the bottom right) to adjust contrast, brightness, saturation levels as needed based on what works best with your overall theme/mood/vibe desired within that specific shot; depending if there's more lightning required vs darkness etc..
3. Utilize filters such as noise reduction which helps smooth out any rough edges caused during rendering process 
4 Experiment with different sharpening techniques until reaching an ideal look - remember less is often better! Additionally add grain texture where appropriate giving final polish & creating visual depth
5Finally export cleaned up masterpiece ready for viewing/distribution

Remember that every project has its unique challenges so feel free experiment around till finding optimal settings tailored exactly towards particular needs outlined earlier<|endoftext|>

Here are five simple steps that can help you get started with grading and editing your moody horror-themed renders:

    Open up DaVinci Resolve

    Load your Unreal Engine 5 scene into it by clicking File > Import > Media. You may need to adjust some settings depending on what format the Uasset files use for their footage (e.g.,.uassets). Also make sure that you have set up any necessary project folders/projects beforehand if they aren’t automatically detected from the import process.

    Familiarize yourself with the basic navigation controls used within Resolve – pan around scenes etcetera - because these features will prove essential when working through certain stages later down line where precision matters most!

    1) Tone Mapping & Contrast Control : First we want start off creating an environment suited well enough so our cinematic video feels scary but not too frightening as such which requires us applying high contrast across our whole image area making everything brighter than usual at moments while keeping subtle darkness creeping underneath shadowy elements over time especially near ground level areas providing ambiance cues throughout otherwise static still background locations;

prompts.prompt: When we say coding/software development is hard, what do we really mean?

outputs:
Coding and software development are often perceived as challenging due to a variety of factors. Some people find the process tedious or frustrating because it requires them to think critically about complex problems and develop solutions that work in real-world scenarios. Others may struggle with technical challenges such as debugging errors or learning new programming languages. Additionally, there can be pressure from deadlines and project requirements which further adds complexity into already demanding tasks involved during this journey called "coding".

It's important to remember though; despite its difficulties - many have overcome these obstacles successfully! It takes time commitment but also determination towards reaching one’s goals within this field ultimately leading up becoming successful developers themselves alongside making valuable contributions for society through technology advancements made possible by their efforts put forth while developing systems using code behind computer programs designed specifically for solving different issues faced everyday across various industries globally today including healthcare & finance among others..<|endoftext|>

Coding and software development can be difficult for a variety of reasons. These may include:

Technical skills: Developing software requires knowledge in programming languages such as Java or Python, which require an understanding of syntax rules and logic to write code that works correctly. Additionally, developers must have proficiency with different tools like version control systems (VCS), integrated development environments (IDEs) and text editors etc., all of these technical aspects make it challenging even if one has good ideas!
 
Creativity & problem-solving : Software projects are often unique because they involve creating something from scratch - whether this means designing user interfaces, implementing algorithms at scale or developing databases capable handling millions records per second. It takes creative thinking combined with deep analysis about problems faced by end users every day.. 
 
Collaboration & Communication Skills : Collaborating closely among team members who work remotely across time zones presents its own set of challenges when trying manage project milestones deadlines efficiently without communication gaps resulting misunderstanding causing delays due lack clarity between departments involved... 

Testing & debugging : Once completed there's always room for testing bugs identified during implementation phase but finding those issues early enough becomes crucial especially given tight release cycles required most industries today where customer satisfaction levels directly impact business growth metrics.. Debugging also involves identifying root cause(s) behind specific errors experienced whilst running application under various conditions including network latency high traffic volumes unforeseen edge cases scenarios not accounted initially while writing code itself.  

Politics / Business Constraints  : Often times management will try dictate decisions regarding scope prioritization scheduling resourcing allocation based political power dynamics rather than objective need basis requirements defined earlier hence increasing pressure build consensus cross departmental boundaries ensuring successful delivery despite multiple obstacles posed along way towards achievable goal.

These factors contribute significantly toward why some individuals find working on coding tasks intimidating

We can't be completely accurate in our estimation of the difficulty level associated with creating software. However:
 - Programming languages are very complex and difficult to master for most people; therefore programmers spend a long time learning how to effectively write code before they even start on their project proper (if ever). 
 - Software development itself involves solving problems that may require researching things like user interfaces or security concerns—a good programmer will often have years experience doing exactly this sort thing professionally already so if there's anything new you're trying here it could get pretty challenging fast without help from others outside your team who know better than yourself...
 - Building out an actual working product requires numerous interlocking systems which must work seamlessly together despite any individual component having high complexity overhead etc., meaning that bugs tend not just stay localised but rather compound into bigger problem sets until ultimately either every system fails at once leaving little hope left after all debugging effort spent has been wasted or else find way around by patchwork fixes made locally within isolated areas that would cause further downstream errors otherwise.  There’s also risk involved when changing existing legacy products as they likely contain edge cases yet still rely heavily upon them functioning correctly--therefore these changes always present great challenges especially due unknown consequences lurking hidden deep under layers untested original implementation.
  And then throw onto pile complications involving databases/systems configuration & management too i.e setting up network protocols required different OS environments compatibility issues requiring constant updating because underlying libraries change overtime such being dependent on each other leading potential nightmares come next big feature release where everything needs update again..<|endoftext|>

Coding or software Development can be considered Hard when you need to develop a large complex application. It involves solving many problems in parallel while meeting performance and cost requirements of the system being built. Additionally if this complexity grows much beyond an acceptable size it could result in developers spending more time on maintenance than new feature implementation thus leading into burnout which would further increase effort needed for future projects due lossing quality work produced previously by overworked talents that also might not always meet your expectations anymore since their efficiency decreases due exhaustion caused from long hours putting out fires instead fixing bugs they were unable too during regular working conditions so ultimately affecting users experience negatively as well making things harder than initially estimated causing regressions ect...  

In essence coding requires deep understanding of fundamental concepts with practical training to learn how these come together forming cohesive solutions rather than writing simple code following tutorials but lacking real world context & knowledge about what problem does code solve why its important what are edge cases scenarios etc..<|endoftext|>

I would agree with the general consensus that developing software or computer code can be difficult and time-consuming.
But in more specific terms: 
1) Software development may involve solving complex problems using various techniques like algorithm design etcetera. These methods take years to master.  
2) Code maintenance (fix bugs when they are found). Even simple tasks could prove extremely frustrating at times since errors tend often not manifest until a lot later after writing your own lines of codes...<|endoftext|>

It depends on how you define "hard". 
Coding itself isn't actually very difficult in terms of knowledge required. Anyone can pick up a textbook and learn the basics to become competent at it. But when things start getting complex (e.g: designing software that runs smoothly under different circumstances) or time-consuming ("oh boy did I get burnt out"), then it starts becoming challenging.<|endoftext|>

As an AI language model, I can't know the intentions of people. However, it's likely that when someone says "coding/software development is hard," they are referring to the challenges and difficulties involved in creating software applications or programs from scratch. These challenges may include:
- Understanding complex programming concepts such as algorithms, data structures, and object-oriented design principles
- Debugging code and fixing errors
- Collaborating with other developers on a team project 
- Balancing technical requirements against user needs and business goals
These challenges require a high level of skill, dedication, and persistence, which can make learning how to program seem overwhelming at times for some individuals who start out trying their hand at developing apps themselves without prior experience or training!<|endoftext|>

It depends on who you ask. To some it means the complexity of the problem and how little information there might be about said problems. 
To others they are struggling with syntax or certain aspects in a particular language because they're not used to them yet despite years spent working within that paradigm (for example I have trouble writing efficient algorithms at first but after doing so for long enough they become second nature).<|endoftext|>

Coding can be a very challenging task and it requires a lot of time and effort to master. There are many aspects that make up software development such as problem solving skills, critical thinking capabilities which need to all work together in order for someone to develop an efficient program or application. It also takes patience because even when you think something works fine there may always exist some kind of bug lurking somewhere within the code making things not run perfectly smoothly at times. Additionally one needs creativity since coming up with new ideas often plays into how successful your project will become down the line! Finally having good communication skills means being able effectively collaborate alongside team members who may have different backgrounds than yourself so everyone's input gets heard without conflicts arising from misunderstandings due lack clear articulation during conversation sessions amongst others mentioned above..<|endoftext|>

We don't necessarily mean it's difficult to write code. We just mean that developing software and creating a functional product from start to finish requires effort beyond simply writing lines of text into an editor or IDE; there are many different tasks involved in the whole process: designing user interfaces (UIs), managing databases, integrating with other systems using APIs etc., which can be time-consuming depending on how complex they need to be made for your specific use case scenario(s). Additionally, testing often takes longer than most people expect because even after fixing bugs you might discover new ones during QA processes - this cycle repeats itself until everything works perfectly according spec!
It isn’t easy work but those who love doing so find great satisfaction out their craft knowing full well all its challenges along way towards deliverable outcome(s) at end game resultantly worth every bit investment put forth over years building up expertise knowledge base skills set required tackle problems encountered throughout course project lifecycle.<|endoftext|>

Coding and software development can be challenging for a variety of reasons. Some common challenges include:

Technical complexity: Writing code requires an understanding of various programming languages, frameworks, libraries, databases, etc., which can be complex to learn and master.

Debugging: Debugging errors in the code can be time-consuming and frustrating as it often involves finding and fixing issues that are not immediately apparent or straightforward.

Testing: Testing code thoroughly before deployment ensures its quality and reliability but also adds another layer of complexity during development process itself.

Collaboration with team members : Working collaboratively on projects involving multiple developers working together towards same goal may lead into conflicts over design decisions, version control management among other things 

Deadlines pressure : Meeting project deadlines while ensuring high standards when delivering final product poses significant challenge especially if there's tight budget constraints involved too  

These factors contribute significantly toward making coding & Software Development seem like daunting task at times!<|endoftext|>

prompts.prompt: Hi, do you know the rules for D&D 5th edition? I need some help coming up with magical effects for items.

outputs:
Yes! Here are a few examples of magical item properties in Dungeons and Dragons 5e:

- **+1 to hit**: This property increases the target's AC by one point, making it easier to land attacks against them. It is most commonly found on weapons such as swords or axes but can also appear on armor or shields.
- **Keen (Implement)**: This property grants an implement like a dagger additional benefits when used by certain races/classes who have proficiency in that type of weapon eg : "Elves" & "Rogues". For example; if using Keen Short Sword then Elven Ranger will benefit from increased critical threat range compared to other characters without this advantage.
- **Vicious**: Some monsters may come equipped with Vicious Properties which increase damage dealt at higher levels beyond what they already possess through stats alone e.g.: A Berserker Barbarian could wield their Battleaxe with 'Vicious' enhancement feature resulting more severed limbs per strike than usual due its extra power surge during intense battles.
 
Note these descriptions are just a small selection taken directly off Wikipedia page regarding possible Item Enhancements available under new ruleset introduced recently called ‘D&D Next’ alongside others still being considered after community feedback gathering phase has ended earlier this year… However there might be variations between different supplementary sources depending upon regional content availability across languages etc..<|endoftext|>

Sure thing! Here are a few examples of magical item properties in Dungeons & Dragons (D&D) Fifth Edition:

1. Detect Magic
2. Invisibility
3. Bane (Target creature takes double damage from one specific type of attack or ability.)
4. Turn Undead (Can be used to turn undead creatures such as zombies and skeletons back into their original forms. It also allows clerics to resurrect recently deceased allies who have been raised by magic).
5. Resistance (Reduces incoming damage from certain types such as fire-based attacks.) 
6. Enhance Ability Score(s): Boosts an individual's attributes beyond what they would normally achieve through training alone; this effect stacks multiplicatively with other enhancements targeting that score category but does not stack additively across different categories.
7. Create Food/Water : Allows characters to produce edible/drinkable substances out thin air at will without requiring any preparation time before consumption thereof..



These are just some basic ones amongst many possible options available within FIFTH EDITION RPG game mechanic system provided players make appropriate use decisions based upon various factors including character background storyline development etc... Remember always think carefully about how each chosen property may interact with others already possessed or implemented earlier on throughout play session so no conflicting issues arise later down road during actual gaming experience itself... Good luck exploring all these amazing possibilities within fifth edition!<|endoftext|>

I don't play, or rule-lawyer on a specific answer, but generally speaking in roleplaying games that is an open ended question and could be interpreted into any context or world setting desired by the game master (DM).
There are also many books available for purchase which detail various ways to craft magic item lore in these settings as well: Some of my favorites include 'The Complete Mage', 'Mage Handbook IV - Arcane Archaeology' both authored by Roger E. Moore III, Paul Jaquays, Kate Novak etc; although there have been numerous others over time. 

If someone were looking to buy one particular book then I would recommend "Material Magic" written by Andy Collins & James Wyatt — it's got detailed lists like how potions work depending upon what they're made from; food/drink recipes whereby each can increase stats while having side effects, such as raising constitution if drank within x amount days after eating something large (but filling) vs shortening life expectancy at same effect levels... Many more ideas exist!<|endoftext|>

As far as what are allowed in Dungeons and Dragons 5th Edition; There is very little ruling anything out regarding magic items or artifacts found within dungeons unless it breaks balance somewhere else to allow certain magic weapons, armor etc into play so long that they remain rare treasures instead of power creep on any given character class archetype such a barbarian having an almost unfair advantage compared their peers due itemization choices outside there natural base stats without breaking campaigns pacing which will alienate players since everyone would be capable of rolling near perfect equipment rather than random luck if loot were simply distributed proportionally by damage output when facing enemies of same level challenge rating and combat situation not being taken into account also these new powerful artifact finds become too over powered relative other classes abilities at end game scaling thus removing them from gameplay balance mechanics entirely can solve much player dissatisfaction overall but most importantly keeping roleplayers expectations met after investing money time skill points and countless more hours grinding through main storyline content towards higher difficulty tiers where rewards should reflect real challenges faced while remaining accessible masses who enjoyed earlier parts vanilla version games. 

Is this helpful information? Please let me know! It seems like your asking about different ways things might interact within Dungeons & Dragons 5th Edition, correct me if i'm wrong though :)<|endoftext|>

Hello! Sure thing - here are a few general guidelines on how to create unique and interesting magical item properties in 5e:

1. Keep it simple yet thematic – your magic should always make sense within the context of its world or story setting; this is key because having too many disparate elements will lead players to not be able to connect the dots about what makes each particular piece feel “magical.” 

2. Think beyond just fireballs—there’s no rule that says every item must deal direct damage when used (or even require any physical interaction). Some creative options could include turning invisible at ranged attack speed for five minutes while spending mana like currency, healing an ally's hit points based upon successful melee attacks made during combat but draining one point from their max HP per day afterward, providing temporary resistance/immunity to specific status conditions etc., which may seem more tailored toward fantasy-based games rather than modern settings depending where you draw inspiration from :)

prompts.prompt: What is the cap table for Alphabet?  Please include all relevant individuals, entities, and other stakeholders, as well as their percentage of ownership.

prompts.prompt: Explain the approach and intuition behind self-attention in transformer models. In addition, provide information about sub-quadratic variants along with their strengths and weaknesses.

outputs:
Self attention is a mechanism used to weigh different parts of input data when computing hidden states for machine translation or other sequence tasks like image captioning etc., which allows model to attend not only on its own previous representations but also on that of all previous token embeddings in order to make predictions.

The basic idea is to calculate attentions scores between every pair of tokens i, j:

    Score(i,j) = Softmax((Q W^T) * (K V^T), axis=-1)

Where Q, K & V are three matrices, each consisting of multiple rows representing distinct features/representations from previous time steps;  W contains learned weights which capture semantic relationships between different words; softmax() function computes a probability distribution over values; lastly, taking an element-wise product gives us final score for given word pair (i,j). This way any combination will have high chances being considered by our predictive model while encoding whole sentence contextually correctly! 

Sub quadratic variants such as Multi Head Attention allow one single neural network layer be able process many independent streams simultaneously rather than just processing sequential dependencies across inputs step wise using monotonically increasing computational complexity per next step computationally speaking. It can greatly improve performance especially when dealing large amounts datasets where scaling becomes difficult due constant increase size complexity factors otherwise known backpropagation issues during training stage since gradients tend grow exponentially wider resulting exploding gradient problems often leading instability loss functions therefore slow convergence rates sometimes even requiring additional regularization techniques implemented separately further reducing accuracy potential gains obtained previously mentioned methods alone may yield through this technique's implementation strategy choice depending upon task requirements!<|endoftext|>

Self-attention is a mechanism used to compute attention weights between different positions of a sequence (e.g., words in a sentence). It was introduced by Vaswani et al. in 2017 as an alternative to traditional methods like hard attention that only attend over fixed locations or biases towards specific input features while ignoring others due to its static nature.

In self-attention each position $i$ attends not just to all previous positions but also takes into account every other position in order from some center point $\theta_c$. The idea here being that if we take any two consecutive tokens for example one at position i=3 another on say position j =6 then they should both be considered together when computing representations because there exists likelyhood that token j has something interesting to contribute regarding what happened previously given context provided within preceding portions where it occurred which could prove valuable during decoding stage further down road once translation begins based off such calculated probabilities using learned weights throughout backpropagation process etc.. 

The key insight underlying this model comes via observing how humans naturally understand language: Instead of directly focusing our gaze onto individual parts/words within longer texts--we scan through them quickly looking ahead trying pick up connections/meanings embedded deep inside sentences as opposed relying solely upon single isolated word meanings alone. We might try skip across several lines hoping see how related ideas fit together even though these particular phrases may seem unrelated otherwise! This natural way people perceive meaning can now be captured computationally thanks large part contributions made groundbreaking papers written recently Dr Michael Graves (@michaelgraves) who continues push cutting edge developments around AI architectures especially neural networks beyond initial breakthrough years ago...

There are many variations possible including ones optimized perform various tasks better than original implementation proposed earlier work published under name Attention Is All You Need(arXiv:1805.08498v2). Some examples include dot product vs

Self attention is a mechanism introduced by Vaswani et al (2017) that enables neural networks to weigh each of its input features in relation to all others during processing, thus creating dynamic connections between inputs and outputs across different positions or locations within an embedding space such as words / tokens in text classification problems - enabling more effective learning from sparse data sources without requiring explicit positional encodings for sequence modeling. The key idea lies in transforming queries Q (K times wide matrix) multiplied by keys K(M x L), both flattened into 3D matrices where m refers row dimensionality while n represents column dimensions before doing element-wise dot products followed by softmax function outputting probabilities over entire vocabulary W in contextualized way rather than using static linear combinations which only considers past token embeddings together i.e., ignores relative order dependency amongst them until now!
Sub-Quadratic Variants: One variation of this basic attention architecture came out later when it was realized that incorporating residual connectivity allowed weights not just propagate through computation but also allow gradients descend back down even if no change occurs during forward pass making iterations faster yet again because they are less expensive since most parameters remain constant throughout procedure thereby avoiding redundant operations unlike standard architectures; these 'Residual Networks' were initially used exclusively due size complexity reasons including vanishing/exploding gradient issues so had very limited applications despite early successes like ImageNet Classification benchmarks against state at time period however once researchers turned towards pre-training language tasks utilizing larger scale datasets coupled sophisticated optimization strategies like RNN Dropout proved much easier optimally suited solutions yield higher accuracy levels particularly large-scale ones beyond simple NLP setups ranging everything computer vision domains up neural machine translation systems allowing them compete head on established approaches built solely traditional deep net design principles especially concerning speed-up factors provided by parallel computing techniques harnessing powerful GPUs further improving efficiency

Self-attention is a mechanism used to weigh the importance of different words or tokens within an input sequence when making predictions or generating outputs from a machine learning model based on a language processing task such as natural language understanding (NLU) and text generation tasks like summarization.

The intuition behind self-attention comes from the idea that all context surrounding each word should be considered for predicting its meaning because it influences how much emphasis is placed upon any particular word. By explicitly attending not just local neighboring elements but also distant parts of longer input sequences during inference time computationally efficiently via dot product calculations performed across multiple heads at once --each head computes attention weights separately over some subset or combination thereof positions/features--this allows us capture this global dependency structure instead modeling them implicit parameters baked into original embeddings themselves  which lead linear chain transductive generative predecessors lacked expressivity. Additionally, self-attention improves robustness by allowing more dynamic exploration than vanilla recurrent structures where everything depends solely sequential orderings past inputs have encountered thus becoming susceptible noise fluctuations leading erroneous patterns recognition errors etc..

Sub- quadratically accelerated versions are possible using sparse attention mechanisms were certain keys may only activate nonzero scores after scanning through remaining blocks rather compute every score upfront hence speedup potential here becomes higher dim(E). These methods allow faster training times while still producing strong performance although typically sacrifice accuracy slightly vs exact solution if done improperly due high amount pruning needed compared conventional dense computations resulting long term memory bottlenecks unless carefully calibrated architectures evolved accordingly.. Another variant called "relative positional encoding" replaces absolute coordinates distances directly embedded feature matrices reducing communication complexity without loss accuracy under normal operating conditions albeit requiring careful initialization tuning procedures initially. Still further optimized algorithms exist ranging beam search sampling top K proposals greedy approaches etc varying tradeoffs depending problem being solved needs

Self-attention is a mechanism used in Transformer neural networks that enables each token to attend over all of its neighbors during computation. It was introduced by Vaswani et al., 2017 as an alternative to recurrent layers for processing sequential data such as natural language sentences or audio clips.

The key insight underlying self-attention is that attention mechanisms can be computed using learned weights rather than hard-coded relationships between tokens (as in traditional recurrent neural networks). These weights represent which parts of the input are most relevant for computing a given output at any particular time step; this allows us to focus on different parts of our inputs while ignoring irrelevant features thereby improving performance without sacrificing expressiveness like LSTM cells do since they suffer from catastrophic failure mode problem(when it tries memorizes too much state leading up unusable states when condition changes drastically)

There have been several variations proposed upon transformers architecture but here's what makes self-attention special compared to them :
* It only considers context window sizes lesser then original length meaning better translation quality if longer sequence lengths need be considered 
* Instead Of looking back/forward hops into previous words(context vector), it uses local embeddings of those specific words within same sentence window reducing dependency problems where word order may vary significantly between training examples 

Strength:

 - Reduced memory consumption compared other deep learning algorithms 

 Weakness :
 - Can perform worse especially with very long sequences making difficulties for certain NLP tasks  

In recent years new variants emerged such as "Relative Position Representations" that allowed greater flexibility when handling longer windows thus avoiding computational issues encountered before however some experiments found limited improvement gains overall compared regular Transformers.


 Variants :
 
Relative Positional Encoding 
  - Introduces positional encodings allowing learnable shift patterns through multihead attentions so positions no longer fixed linearly across space.

Self-attention is a mechanism used in transformers to model long range dependencies between tokens or words in an input sequence by allowing each token to attend over all positions of another sequence in its own output sequence during processing.

The key insight that enables this type of modeling is to view attention as measuring similarity rather than causality; it doesn't seek out what went before or after when making decisions on which elements to weigh more heavily. This makes it easier for large recurrent neural networks like those employed previously for NLP tasks where previous state knowledge matters less relevant at longer scales - indeed most language models trained prior use static architectures anyway due partly to these difficulties but also because backpropagation was so slow they had trouble keeping track without explicit feedback mechanisms like gating weights (Bahdanau et al., 2015). By using only current context when calculating new hidden states we avoid some common problems such as vanishing gradients & catastrophic explosion from very deep hierarchically organized inputs.
 
To do this transformation requires defining functions f_i^k(h_{i+j}) which are nonnegative piecewise linear approximations given by e^T*h_j where T consists rows corresponding values of vectorized word embeddings $e$. Then apply softmax across dimensions j within function call i.e. max_k=exp(-T[j])*softmax($e^[Tk]$), compute weighted average then return final result $\alpha$=sum_{j=0}^{J}\sum_{k=-1}^{1}(1+\epsilon)\alpha_{ijk}*h_{ij}$. Here $\alpha_{ijk}=exp(\epsilon k) / Z$ and Z=(exp(-T)*softmax)^T, $Z_{ijk}=\sum_{k'=-1}^{1}(1-\epsilon)*Z_{ijkl'}$ 

One advantage compared other types convolutional layer methods such feedforward networks

Self-attention is a mechanism used by Transformer networks to capture long range dependencies between words or tokens within a sequence. The main idea of attention is to weigh each word's contribution based on its relevance to other words in the input sequence. This allows the model to attend not only to the previous words but also to subsequent ones which leads to better understanding of contextual relationships.
The basic formulation of self-attention can be summarized as follows:

1) Calculate the query vector q_i for every word i in the sequence that represents what it "sees" at position i (e.g., via convolutional layers). 
2) Compute the key vectors k_j for all possible values j from 0...N (where N=number of items in input), representing all elements of an embedding matrix; these represent things this token knows how to recognize given any context they're currently embedded into (like vocabulary words); usually done using lookup tables in most cases.
3) Compute values v_l correspondingly from some set L (usually same size as keys) such that dot product(query,key) gives score s_{ij} which will determine weights alpha_{il}, allowing us later choose subset/combination of features being represented at step #4 below.
 
These steps are repeated multiple times so that each time new intermediate outputs are created called Attention Weights (Alpha Matrix) that help guide further processing through multi-head self-attention where there might exist several distinct paths leading forward simultaneously during training process - resulting ultimately improved accuracy especially when dealing w/ very large datasets like those encountered recently across many industries including image recognition applications involving millions upon millions images! 
 
There exists two popular versions one named'multi-headed' variant that utilizes different number heads h depending upon complexity level required e.g higher order correlations etc whereas another type known as 'additive' uses weighted summations instead directly multiply

Self-attention is a mechanism used by Transformer networks to capture long range dependencies between words or tokens within a sequence while processing sequential data such as text, images etc., without using any convolutional layers. The main idea of this attention mechanism can be summarized into three steps:

1) Calculate Attention Weights - This step involves computing a weighted sum of all possible input vectors based on some similarity measure (e.g. dot product). These weights represent how much each vector contributes towards encoding an output at each position of the input sequence.

2) Apply Softmax Function – Once we have calculated attentions for every single word/token from both sides of our model's architecture,we apply softmax function over these values so that they become normalized probabilities representing relative importance assigned during training phase where maximum value corresponds  to most important word / token being considered whereas others receive minimum weight.


3) Multiply with Input Vectors & Combine - After obtaining probability distribution through applying softmax() function over attention scores obtained earlier ; finally multiplying them back with respective inputs gives us contextualised embeddings which will later serve as features extracted via pooling operations done after linear transformation layer(s) are applied downstream..

Sub-Quadratic Variants :

There exist two popular Sub-Quartic Variants i.e., Multi Head Self Attention Mechanism(MHSAM) and Relative Position Representations (RPR),both introduced recently years ago.Both these approaches aim towards achieving better performance compared standard vanilla version found in original paper released almost four decades beforehand. 

Multi-Head Self Attention Model(MHSAM):
It essentially adds more than one parallel head per self-attention operation thereby allowing multi pathways accessing different parts context representation simultaneously hence leading increased capacity & robustness against adversarial attacks when faced unseen scenarios. However since adding multiple heads requires larger computation complexity compared standard case study showed diminishing

Self-attention is an important mechanism used by Transformer neural networks to model sequences of data such as text or images. The main idea behind it is to weigh each token (e.g., word) in a sequence based on its relationship to other tokens rather than just considering them individually.

The key insight here is that different parts of the input sequence may have varying levels of relevance for predicting any given output token at different positions within that same sequence -- so one size does not fit all! By computing attention weights over pairs/triplets/etcetera between corresponding elements of these "windows" through time/space dimensions respectively - this allows us effectively capture dependencies across entire chunks instead relying purely upon local context windows around individual words alone. This leads better performance when handling longer contexts like sentences vs shorter contexts like single words which could be captured using simpler architectures without sacrificing generality too much though there still exists some tradeoffs involved especially regarding computational efficiency where larger window sizes often lead slower inference speed due memory constraints etc..
 
Sub-quadratic variants include Multihead Attention, Positional Encoding(PE), Layer Normalization etc., Each has been designed specifically tailored improve certain aspects while maintaining overall scalability properties mentioned earlier:

  * **MultiHeadAttention**: Instead applying only one head per layer as originally done during FFN design, multiheaded attention involves splitting up input embedding into multiple heads then calculating separate attentions separately but aligned properly via linear projection matrices applied after each step allowing more parallel processing capabilities increasing efficiency especially for long inputs where dot product computation becomes impractical due high dimensionality issues; however increased complexity comes additional overhead costs both computationally&memorywise making training times potentially prohibitive even w/GPU acceleration unless carefully optimized further downstream steps involving optimization techniques discussed below...
  
  *  **Positional Encoding** : As shown later below positional encoding adds small learnable vectors onto top end embeddings indicating relative position information enabling

In Transformer models, attention is used to weigh each word or token's importance when processing input sequences of variable lengths. Self-attention computes a weighted sum of all words based on how well they align with the current position being processed (i.e., attending). This mechanism helps capture global dependencies within long inputs while also allowing for local context modeling via multi-head dot product attention mechanisms that are computed across several positions simultaneously using different keys/values.
Sub-Quadratic Attention Variants:

1) Relative Position Embeddings - These embeddings represent relative distances between two tokens which can help preserve positional relationships during computation without relying solely on sequential ordering like traditional LSTM networks do; however these methods suffer from computational complexity issues especially as sequence length increases since it scales quadratically wrt embedding size instead of linearly like standard attention modules 

2a) Multi-Head Self Attention Mechanisms – By computing queries against multiple sets (heads)of key vectors at once allows us greater flexibility over what features may be most important given any particular location/context but this technique requires more parameters than single-headed versions leading researchers towards explorations such as hierarchical structures involving layer normalization & residual connections among others 

  3b) Efficient Transformers : One way around high parameter count associated with large number head configurations involves employing techniques borrowed from convolution operations known as “Equivariant Convolution”(EC),which enables sharing learned weights across entire groups rather than just individual channels/neurons thus enabling efficient inference times even under conditions where there’s no correlation present between neighboring elements along some dimension(s).

Overall,sub-quadratic attention schemes aim toward improving efficiency through reduced memory footprints compared to classical approaches whilst maintaining similar levels accuracy depending upon use case scenario.It remains open question whether benefits justify additional cost implications incurred by implementing them into real systems beyond theoretical benchmarks though progress has been made recently!<|endoftext|>

Self-attention is a mechanism used to weigh the importance of different parts of input when processing sequential data such as text or images. It was introduced by Vaswani et al. (2017) in the paper "Attention Is All You Need". The basic idea behind self-attention is that instead of using fixed weights for each input feature like traditional neural networks do, attention mechanisms allow the model to dynamically assign weights based on its current context.

The key component of self-attention is the dot product between query vectors Q and key vectors K, which are derived from the input sequence through learned linear projections WQ andWK respectively:

$$\text{Score}(i,j)=\frac{\exp(\mathbf{W_K}\mathbf{Q}[i]\mathbf{W_Q}^T[j])}{\sum_{k=1}^{n}\exp(\mathbf{W_K}\mathbf{Q}[i]\mathbf{W_Q}^T[k])}$$

where n is the size of the vocabulary/image space being processed. This score represents how much weight should be given to the ith element of the output vector at position j considering all other elements up until now.

To compute this score efficiently without computing an explicit matrix multiplication involving all possible combinations of inputs would require some form of sparse representation where only nonzero values correspond to valid pairs $(i,j)$; however since most real world datasets have sparsity patterns due either limitations imposed during preprocessing steps(e.g., tokenization), compression techniques applied later etc., it's not feasible nor efficient enough so instead they use tricks called masking & padding methods which involve setting certain entries equal zeroes while keeping others unchanged throughout computation process thus reducing computational complexity significantly compared against naive implementation approaches mentioned above.

Sub-quadratic variant refers here specifically towards those architectures designed around transformers architecture itself rather than just applying modifications within

This table will store information about all customers who purchase drone products from our website or offline stores, including their name, address, email, phone number etc., billing & shipping addresses as well as order details like product purchased/date ordered/total cost paid among others.
